definition:
A generic *integral transform* takes the form
$$F(p)  =  \int_\alpha^\beta K(p, t) f(t)dt,$$ with $p$ being the
[*transform parameter*]{}.

Note that the transform takes a function $f(t)$ and produces a new
function $F(p)$.

The function $K(p, t)$ is called the *kernel* of the transform. The
kernel of an integral transform, along with the $\alpha$ and $\beta$,
distinguish a particular integral transform from another.

Examples {#examples .unnumbered}
--------

-   Laplace transform $$\begin{gathered}
    \alpha = 0,\; \beta = \infty,\; K(p,t) = e^{-pt},\\
    F(p) = \int\limits_0^\infty e^{-pt} f(t) dt.\end{gathered}$$

-   Laplace-Carson transform $$\begin{gathered}
    \alpha = 0,\; \beta = \infty,\; K(p,t) = pe^{-pt},\\
    F(p) = \int\limits_0^\infty pe^{-pt} f(t) dt.\end{gathered}$$

-   Fourier transform $$\begin{gathered}
    \alpha = -\infty,\; \beta = \infty,\; K(p,t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-ipt},\\
    F(p) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}
        \int\limits_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-ipt} f(t) dt.\end{gathered}$$
